items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are:   short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
The District is required to submit a a Five-Year Construction Plan annually to the State Chancellor's Office.  This plan is required to be adopted by the Board of Trustees.
 
The submittal of the District's Five-Year Construction Plan is required under provisions of the Community College Construction Act (California Education Code Section 81800 at seq.)
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the 2012-2016 Five-Year Capital Construction Plan as required under provisions of the Community College Construction Act.

items.item_details:
The project scope includes the provision of LEED Fundamental and Enhanced commissioning services for this project.  Project commissioning is a requirement by the USGBC for LEED certification and rating.  These services are provided as an independent third party resource on behalf of the district. 
 
Three proposals were received and the proposal submitted by Interface Engineering was selected based on cost, qualifications and experience and references.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve a Professional Services Agreement with Interface Engineering in an amount not to exceed $28,500.00, to provide LEED Fundamental and Enhanced Commissioning services for the Fitness Center project at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_text: Association of Chief Human Resource Officers/Equal Employment Opportunity Officers (ACHRO/EEO) Fall Training Institute (October 20-22, 2010)
items.item_text_raw: 19. Association of Chief Human Resource Officers/Equal Employment Opportunity Officers (ACHRO/EEO) Fall Training Institute (October 20-22, 2010)

items.item_details: Oral reports will be given by members of the Board of Trustees.
Oral reports will be given by Chancellor Rita Cepeda.
Oral reports will be given by the college presidents.
Oral reports will be given by the constituency representatives.

Background
	 
In December 2009, the Board of Trustees of the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District initiated a review of administrative and oversight procedures for the District.  One of the actions resulting from this undertaking was to commission a set of three independent reports designed to review allegations and concerns raised with respect to financial and administrative matters. These reports were submitted to the Board between May and June 2010. The reports included findings and recommendations that clarified the record with respect to many allegations and concerns. For ease of access a link to these reports follows:  
 
	 
http://www.sjeccd.edu/news/newsrelease/Pages/052110.aspx
	 
	 
The Board of Trustees and administration are taking the concerns very seriously by proposing and approving recommendations to strengthen oversight and accountability. Several proactive steps have already been taken to address the concerns raised in these reports.  The Board Policy Committee was formed in February 2010 and has held monthly meetings to review and strengthen certain policies, and the full Board of Trustees has already taken action in key policy areas.  District administration, similarly, has issued specific directives to District Office staff to strengthen existing administrative procedures and guidelines to ensure compliance.  
	 
In particular, the Board directed the Chancellor to complete a systematic review of each of these three reports and to develop a management tool designed to address areas of concern, including a workplan with periodic reporting to the full Board on progress made.
	 
To date several policies have been developed or revised and an analysis of all three reports has been completed.  This analysis yielded major thematic areas of focus to guide future work including oversight, compliance and accountability measures with respect to the Chancellor, trustees, and administration. The District Foundation is also reviewing all concerns raised and is working on revising its operational guidelines.  
	 
	 
Next Steps
	 
A.  Prepare a Workplan designed to address the areas described above by implementing one or more of the actions described below: 
Develop New Policies- in areas where no explicit policy is currently in place.
Revise Existing Policies--in areas where policies are in place but need updating or strengthening.           
Develop New Procedures--in policy areas where explicit guidelines for implementation are not in place.  
Revise Existing Procedures--in policy areas where current procedures need to be made clearer and more explicit.   
B. Establish Compliance and Enforcement Staff Development Training --in areas where policies and procedures are clearly in place but uneven enforcement is found.  A proposed, systematic and periodic staff development process will be put in place to ensure uniform implementation and compliance with existing policies and procedures.
	 
C.  Establish a Periodic Reporting Calendar--to be presented to the Board of Trustees on the progress and implementation of the proposed workplan.
items.item_recommendation: To accept the independent reports commissioned by the Board namely; two reports prepared by Meyers Nave, Professional Law Corporation dated May 21 and June 4, 2010 respectively and a third report prepared by the Fiscal and Crisis Management Team (FCMAT) dated June 11, 2010; and that the Board approve the set of actions proposed by the Chancellor designed to strengthen the District through a demonstrated accountabilty process.
items.item_text: Acceptance of Independent Reports Findings, Proposed Responses and Next Steps
items.item_text_raw: 1. Acceptance of Independent Reports Findings, Proposed Responses and Next Steps

items.item_details: CA DREAM ACT is a bill introduced by Senate member Gilbert Cedillo with principal authorship by Assembly members Tony Mendoza and John A. Perez.  This bill would permit AB540 students to receive State University grants, University of California grants, scholarships and certain types of loans.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the California DREAM Act resolution urging the Governor's support.

items.item_details:
Hispanic Heritage Month is the period to recognize the contributions of Latinos/Hispanic Americans to the United States and to celebrate Hispanic/Latino heritage and culture. The observation started in 1968 as Hispanic Heritage Week under President Lyndon Johnson and was expanded by President Ronald Reagan in 1988 to cover a 30-day period starting on September 15 and ending on October 15. It was enacted into law on August 17, 1988 on the approval of Public Law 100-402.
	 
September 15 was chosen as the starting point for the celebration because it is the anniversary of independence of five Latin American countries: Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua. They all declared independence in 1821. In addition, Mexico and Chile celebrate their independence days on September 16 and September 18, respectively." [1] Public Law 100-402 authorizes and requests the President to issue an annual proclamation designating September 15 through October 15, as "Hispanic Heritage Month."
	 
October 12, Columbus Day or Día de la Raza, also falls within this 30 day period.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the Hispanic Heritage Month Resolution

items.item_details: Chancellor Cepeda and Vice Chancellor Hawk will provide a budget update.
Chancellor Cepeda will provide a Legislative Update.
Trustee Richard Hobbs, Chair of the Board Policy Committee, will provide an update on the work of the committee.

The Board Policy Committee has been meeting once a month for the purpose of reviewing and strengthening existing Board policies. The Committee has reviewed and revised the district's travel policy, BP 6304. This policy has been reviewed and approved by the District Council and will be sent to the academic senates for their review and input. It is being presented to the Board for a first reading.

In 2009, the Office of Research and Institutional Effectiveness identified nine steps that influence student success for EVC students.  Specifically, students should complete a placement assessment, orientation, counseling services, financial considerations, class enrollment, class attendance, classroom teaching and learning, class success and college-level course completion.  This presentation will focus on the third step of the student success process, counseling and advisement.

The "March in March" film was created by two students, Ryan Keenan and Tony La Rosa.  The film highlights San Jose City College's trip to Sacramento where students, faculty and staff advocated for a fair budget for California Community Colleges.  The film also demonstrates the strength in the number of students who are willing to fight for their education and futures.
